Leslie_Satcher:
{{short description|American singer-songwriter}} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2020}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Leslie Satcher | image = | caption = | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Leslie Winn Satcher | birth_place = Paris, Texas, U.S. | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1962}} | death_date = | origin = | instrument = Vocals | genre = [[Country music|Country]]
[[Bluegrass music|Bluegrass]] | occupation = Singer-songwriter | years_active = 1989–present | label = [[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros.]] | website = http://lesliesatcher.com/ }} '''Leslie Winn Satcher''' (born 1962) is a singer-songwriter based in [[Nashville]], [[Tennessee]]. She has recorded two albums of her own, and has additionally co-written several singles for such artists as [[George Strait]], [[Martina McBride]], [[Pam Tillis]], [[Gretchen Wilson]], [[Patty Loveless]], and [[Vince Gill]]. ==Biography and career== Leslie grew up in her birthplace of [[Paris, Texas|Paris]], Texas, United States, where she sang in local churches and schools – an experience which she lists as one of her biggest influences.{{cite web| title = Letters From Leslie| publisher = [[Country Music Television]]| year = 2001| url = http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1472356/20030606/satcher_leslie.jhtml| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070930040721/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1472356/20030606/satcher_leslie.jhtml| url-status = dead| archive-date = September 30, 2007| accessdate = June 21, 2007 }} In 1989, she moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]] to pursue her dream of being a country music singer, but found a niche writing the songs for which she is most well known – including many by notable country music acts like [[Patty Loveless]], [[Vince Gill]], [[Willie Nelson]], and [[Reba McEntire]].{{cite news | last = Tarradell| first = Mario| title = This train is bound for glory| publisher = [[Dallas Morning News]]| date = April 2, 2002}}{{cite web| title = H.C.R. No. 106| publisher = [[Texas State Legislature]]| date = February 2, 2007| url = http://www.legis.state.tx.us/tlodocs/80R/billtext/html/HC00106I.htm| accessdate = June 21, 2007 }} [[Pam Tillis]] reached No. 12 on the country charts in 1998 with Satcher's "I Said a Prayer". In 2002, [[Martina McBride]]'s performance of her song "[[When God-Fearin' Women Get the Blues]]" reached No. 8 in the United States, while her 2006 song "Politically Uncorrect", performed by [[Merle Haggard]] and [[Gretchen Wilson]], reached No. 23 and was nominated for a Grammy award.{{cite web| title = Students to perform at Country Music Hall of Fame| publisher = [[Country Music Hall of Fame]]| date = April 2, 2006| url = http://www.countrymusichalloffame.com/site/news_detail.aspx?cid=2025| accessdate = June 21, 2007| url-status = dead| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070501201911/http://www.countrymusichalloffame.com/site/news_detail.aspx?cid=2025| archivedate = May 1, 2007}} At the same time, her singing career also began to take off, following her signing with [[Warner Bros. Records]], and the release of her first album ''[[Love Letters (Leslie Satcher album)|Love Letters]]'' in 2002. This was followed by the independent release of ''[[Creation (Leslie Satcher album)|Creation]]'' in 2005, which she has been touring to promote.{{cite web|last=Mackay |first=Jacquie |title=Who writes the songs for the Nashville greats? |publisher=[[ABC Records|ABC]] |date=April 3, 2006 |url=http://www.abc.net.au/capricornia/stories/s1606735.htm |accessdate=June 21, 2007 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060819124152/http://www.abc.net.au/capricornia/stories/s1606735.htm |archivedate=August 19, 2006 }} Her work has met with critical acclaim, with the [[Texas State Legislature]] calling her:
[Able] to craft songs that capture the ears and hearts of music lovers and honoring her [...] for bringing further acclaim to the illustrious musical reputation of the Lone Star State; and, be it further [..] an expression of high regard by the Texas House of Representatives and Senate.
[[USA Today]] listed her as part of a "groundswell" in traditional country and bluegrass music.{{cite web| last = Mansfield| first = Brian| title = O country music, where art thou?| publisher = [[USA Today]]| date = July 9, 2007| url = https://www.usatoday.com/life/music/2001-07-09-country-usat.htm| accessdate = June 21, 2007 }} Leslie Satcher continues to write and sing, after taking some time off in 2006. In 2008, two songs she co-wrote with [[Monty Holmes]], "[[Troubadour (song)|Troubadour]]" and "House Of Cash" were recorded by [[George Strait]]. In 2017, Leslie and The Electric Honey Badgers released the single "This Won't Take Long", featuring [[Vince Gill]] and [[Sheryl Crow]].{{Cite news|url=https://musicrow.com/2017/09/leslie-satcher-joined-by-vince-gill-sheryl-crow-on-new-single-out-today/|title=Leslie Satcher Joined By Vince Gill, Sheryl Crow On New Single, Out Today|date=September 2, 2017|work=MusicRow – Nashville's Music Industry Publication – News, Songs From Music City|access-date=September 27, 2017|language=en-US}} ==Discography== ===Albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! style="width:10em;"| Title ! style="width:18em;"| Album details |- ! scope="row"| ''[[Love Letters (Leslie Satcher album)|Love Letters]]'' | * Release date: November 14, 2000 * Label: [[Warner Bros. Records]] |- ! scope="row"| ''Creation'' | * Release date: July 18, 2005 * Label: Jellan Records |} ===Singles=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! Year ! style="width:16em;"| Single ! Album |- | rowspan="3"| 2001 ! scope="row"| "Love Letters from Old Mexico" | rowspan="4"| ''Love Letters'' |- ! scope="row"| "Burn Me Down" |- ! scope="row"| "[[Ode to Billie Joe]]" |- | 2002 ! scope="row"| "Slow Way Home" |- |2017 ! scope="row"|"This Won't Take Long" | |} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://lesliesatcher.com/ Leslie Satcher's homepage] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20040403204357/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/satcher_leslie/artist.jhtml Profile at Country Music Television] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070607163634/http://www.csusa.org/caw/caw_2006_press_articles_satcher.htm Leslie Satcher on copyright awareness] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Satcher, Leslie}} [[Category:1962 births]] [[Category:Singer-songwriters from Texas]] [[Category:American women country singers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American country singer-songwriters]] [[Category:American bluegrass musicians]] [[Category:People from Paris, Texas]] [[Category:Warner Records artists]] [[Category:Country musicians from Texas]] [[Category:21st-century American women]]
